snippet: Sunday’s array of regional and local elections served as a measure of whether electoral reforms introduced last year would usher in real political competition.
abstract: Russians vote in nearly 5,000 regional and local elections, as opposition candidates attempt to take advantage of electoral laws loosened in response to demands for open political competition; candidates from Pres Vladimir V Putin's United Russia party are nonetheless favored to win most elections, buoyed by low turnout and weak competitors.

byline.original: By ELLEN BARRY and ANDREW ROTH
byline.contributor: Ellen Barry reported from Moscow, and Andrew Roth from Khimki, Russia.

lead_paragraph: Sunday’s array of regional and local elections served as a measure of whether electoral reforms introduced last year would usher in real political competition.

headline.seo: In Russia, Protesters Try to Gain Foothold via Elections
headline.main: Ruling Party Shows Strength Amid Low Turnout in Russian Vote
headline.print_headline: Ruling Party Shows Strength Amid Low Turnout in Russian Vote
